metadata.chief_complaint: annual physical, on ADHD med + melatonin + daily vitamin, growth check, BMI counseling

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hey Ryan! Here for your yearly checkup. How's third grade going?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Good. We have a class pet now, a hamster.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Cool! What's its name?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Speedy. But he's actually kind of slow.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ha! Let me talk to Mom for a minute, then I'll check you out.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: He's doing well overall. The ADHD medication has really helped at school.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's great. Let me review his meds. He's on Concerta 27 milligrams every morning, right?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes. And melatonin two milligrams at bedtime because the Concerta was keeping him up. Plus a daily vitamin.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any side effects from the Concerta? Appetite, mood, headaches?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: His appetite is still low at lunch. He makes up for it at dinner and on weekends.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's typical. We'll watch his weight. Speaking of which, let me get his measurements.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ryan, hop on the scale. Fifty-eight pounds. And let's get your height. Fifty inches.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, so his BMI is 15.9, which is 40th percentile. He's actually dropped from 50th percentile last year.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Is that because of the medication?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Possibly. Stimulant medications can suppress appetite and affect growth. He's still in normal range, but I want to watch this.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should we change medications?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Not yet. He's doing well academically and behaviorally on this dose. Let's try some strategies first. Give him a good breakfast before the medication kicks in. Pack calorie-dense snacks. And encourage eating after the medication wears off in the evening.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: We already do a big breakfast. I can try more snacks.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Also, consider a medication holiday on weekends if his behavior is manageable without it. That gives his appetite a chance to recover.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: We tried that but he's a handful without it. Maybe we can try again over summer.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's reasonable. Summer is a good time for drug holidays.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ryan, come let me listen to your heart.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Heart sounds good. Lungs are clear. Let me see your throat. Say ahh. Looks fine.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Does he need any shots?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: No vaccines due today. His next round is at eleven.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Perfect. He'll be happy about that.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Ryan, you're all done! Keep being awesome in school.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Can I get a sticker?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Absolutely. Mom, let's recheck his weight in three months. If he's still trending down, we might adjust the medication.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Sounds good. I'll schedule the weight check.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Keep the melatonin and vitamin going. Same doses. Call if any concerns.
